justification: The article notes that "the diffusion decision model (Ratcliff, 1978)… could be applied to predict response times as a function of evidence accumulation," indicating this model is the instrument used to quantify the evidence-accumulation construct.

It states that "likelihood-free methods can be used to better implement standard models like the leaky competing accumulator model (Miletić et al., 2017)," treating that model as the tool for capturing dynamics of multi-alternative decisions.

In the lane-change example, an autonomous vehicle "equipped with a cognitive model of behavior, such as approach-avoidance dynamics (Townsend & Busemeyer, 2014)," would infer the driver’s goal—showing this model is proposed to measure/estimate driving intent.

The paper explains that "ML-assisted models" allow researchers "to rapidly estimate latent processes – such as risk propensity… – from behavioral data," describing these machine-learning-based models as the measurement approach for risk propensity.
